entry.title: Will unrest derail South Africa's Covid-19 fight? | The Stream

media:group.media:title: Will unrest derail South Africa's Covid-19 fight? | The Stream
media:group.media:description:
A third wave of coronavirus cases sweeping South Africa is pushing frontline medical workers to the limit, with continuing unrest over economic inequality hampering access to essential supplies.
Hospitals and doctors’ offices across the country have been overwhelmed by growing numbers of patients in recent weeks. Some hospitals are completely full, while stocks of oxygen are at critically-low levels. Almost two-thirds of recent cases have been registered in Gauteng province, home to South Africa’s administrative capital Pretoria and Johannesburg, the country's largest city.
Over the course of the coronavirus pandemic more than 65,000 people in South Africa have died due to COVID-19, with more than 2.2 million cases recorded. But restrictions on movement to check the spread of coronavirus during the third wave are also complicating government efforts to address discontent over poverty and inequality. Protests sparked by the imprisonment of former president Jacob Zuma for corruption have since mushroomed into a wider expression of anger over dire economic prospects.
Health authorities are now racing to vaccinate millions of South Africans to help arrest coronavirus cases. But while the government is aiming to vaccinate about 300,000 people a day by the end of August, so far only 4.6 million vaccine doses have been administered within South Africa’s roughly 60 million population.
In this episode of The Stream, we’ll look at the human impact of the latest wave of coronavirus cases in South Africa and what it will take for the country to get one step ahead of the Delta variant.
Join the conversation: TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AJStream FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/AJStream Subscribe to our channel http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
#aljazeeraenglish #ajstream #southafrica

entry.title: How to stop racism in football? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: How to stop racism in football? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
Last Sunday's Euro Championship final was meant to be a unifying moment for England, who reached that stage for the first time in 55 years. Instead, three black players who helped achieve that accomplishment, faced a barrage of racial abuse from fans online after missing penalties. UK Prime minister Boris Johnson has pledged to ban those who racially abuse footballers from stadiums for up to ten years. He's also threatening to fine tech companies if they fail to prevent racist content appearing on their platforms. So, why is the abuse happening now?
Presenter: Folly Bah Thibault
Guests:
Clarke Carlisle - A former Premier League player and Co-chair of the Players Advisory Board at Kick It Out.
Anita Abayomi - A Sports Journalist and the Co-Founder and host of Goal Diggers podcast.
Paul Kearns - Deputy Chief Executive of Show Racism the Red Card.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: At least 33 killed as heavy rains batter western Germany

media:group.media:title: At least 33 killed as heavy rains batter western Germany
media:group.media:description:
At least 33 people have died and dozens are missing, according to regional officials, after heavy rains triggered flash floods in parts of Germany, damaging homes and disrupting transport. The deaths reported on Thursday were in the states of North Rhine-Westphalia and Rhineland-Palatinate where around the wine-growing hub of Ahrweiler 18 people died due to the extreme weather conditions. In the small town of Schuld in Rhineland-Palatinate, four houses were swept away by rising floodwaters, while two others were partly washed away. Some 50 to 70 people are missing, the authorities said. “There are people dead, there are people missing, there are many who are still in danger,” the governor of Rhineland-Palatinate state, Malu Dreyer, told the regional parliament. “We have never seen such a disaster. It’s really devastating.”
Al Jazeera's Jillian Wolf reports.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Lebanon: PM-designate Saad Hariri resigns as crisis escalates

media:group.media:title: Lebanon: PM-designate Saad Hariri resigns as crisis escalates
media:group.media:description:
Lebanon Prime Minister-designate Saad Hariri stepped down on Thursday after failing to form a government for over the past eight months.
Hariri resigned following a brief meeting with President Michel Aoun at Baabda Palace.
“I withdrew from forming the government,” he told reporteres. “And may god save this country.”
Political deadlock has persisted since Hariri’s reappointment last October, despite diplomatic pressure from France, Saudi Arabia, and the United States. The European Union has threatened to implement sanctions on Lebanese officials.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Largest US car expo to open again after COVID break

media:group.media:title: Largest US car expo to open again after COVID break
media:group.media:description:
The coronavirus pandemic has put the brakes on auto shows around the world over the last year and a half. But that is about to change, with the return of the largest car expo in North America. Al Jazeera's John Hendren got a preview of the Chicago Auto Show before it opens on Thursday.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Gambia economy struggles to recover after COVID restrictions lifted

media:group.media:title: Gambia economy struggles to recover after COVID restrictions lifted
media:group.media:description:
Business activities may be normalising slowly in The Gambia after COVID-19 restrictions were lifted. But two of the country’s key economic sectors - diaspora remittances and tourism - continue to flounder. They make up about half of the country’s Gross domestic product (GDP). Experts are warning that unless they recover fast, the future of the economy could be in trouble. Al Jazeera's Ahmed Idris reports from the capital, Banjul.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: US: Vaccination hesitancy threatens to hamper herd immunity efforts

media:group.media:title: US: Vaccination hesitancy threatens to hamper herd immunity efforts
media:group.media:description:
It is feared vaccine hesitancy among young adults in the US is hampering efforts to achieve herd immunity against COVID-19. Those aged below 25 are getting jabs at half the rate of older Americans. That has prompted some young people to try and counter the deluge of misinformation online. Al Jazeera's Heidi Zhou-Castro reports.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Athlete, Olympic workers test positive for COVID as opening nears

media:group.media:title: Athlete, Olympic workers test positive for COVID as opening nears
media:group.media:description:
Eight days to go to Tokyo 2020, and Olympics chief Thomas Bach says there is "zero chance" of participants infecting Japanese residents with coronavirus. Those comments came on the same day that one athlete and several staff members at the games tested positive in Tokyo. Al Jazeera's David Stokes reports.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Azeri heritage sites: Casualties of Nagorno-Karabakh conflict

media:group.media:title: Azeri heritage sites: Casualties of Nagorno-Karabakh conflict
media:group.media:description:
Last year, civilians on both sides of the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region were caught up in the worst fighting in more than 25 years. And despite a ceasefire between Armenia and Azerbaijan, there are still concerns about another casualty of war - cultural heritage sites. Al Jazeera's Resul Serdar reports from Khojavend in Azerbaijan.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Iran faces fifth COVID wave amid growing Delta variant threat

media:group.media:title: Iran faces fifth COVID wave amid growing Delta variant threat
media:group.media:description:
Iran is facing a fifth wave of COVID-19 as the new Delta variant continues to spread. The country is already the worst-affected in the Middle East, with 3.5 million people infected and more than 86,000 deaths. Al Jazeera's Dorsa Jabbari has more on how Iran’s vaccination programme is slowly getting under way.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Taliban, Afghan government both claim control of border crossing | Al Jazeera Newsfeed

media:group.media:title: Taliban, Afghan government both claim control of border crossing | Al Jazeera Newsfeed
media:group.media:description:
Afghanistan’s government says it has retaken a strategic border crossing that was captured by the Taliban on Wednesday, but the group says it remains firmly in control of the Spin Boldak-Chaman border post.

entry.title: What’s behind the US trade in exotic animals? | The Bottom Line

media:group.media:title: What’s behind the US trade in exotic animals? | The Bottom Line
media:group.media:description:
"The Conservation Game" dives deep into the trafficking of exotic animals, especially big cats like lions, tigers and leopards, across the United States.
For decades, TV personalities have trotted cute “ambassador animals” onto morning and late-night talk shows to talk about conservation and animal protection. But this documentary by Michael Webber shows us what happens afterwards when the animals are sold off at auction or kept in back yard cages on private property.
Host Steve Clemons asks about this largely unregulated trade in the US with Webber, Big Cat Rescue founder Carole Baskin, and legal expert Carney Anne Nasser.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Texas Democrats defy arrest, pledge to remain in Washington over voting rights

media:group.media:title: Texas Democrats defy arrest, pledge to remain in Washington over voting rights
media:group.media:description:
More than 50 Democratic members of the Texas legislature remain in the US capital. They fled to Washington, DC on Monday to stop the Texan House of Representatives from reaching a quorum – the minimum number of members needed to conduct business. They said it was the only way to prevent new state laws to suppress voter rights for minorities from being passed.
Al Jazeera’s Shihab Rattansi reports from the US capital, Washington, DC.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#ForthePeopleAct #TexasVotingRights #JoeBiden

entry.title: Iraq: Protests break out in Nasiriya following deadly hospital fire

media:group.media:title: Iraq: Protests break out in Nasiriya following deadly hospital fire
media:group.media:description:
Protesters in Iraq are demanding answers from the government after a hospital fire killed more than 90 people on Monday. The families of victims accuse health officials of negligence and corruption. The government has set up a commission to investigate the incident. Security officials of Dhi Qar province have accepted the mistakes.
Al Jazeera’s Mahmoud Abdelwahed reports from Nasiriya, Iraq.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#Iraq #AlHusseinHospitalFire #Nasiriyah

entry.title: US charges four with plot to kidnap journalist critical of Iran

media:group.media:title: US charges four with plot to kidnap journalist critical of Iran
media:group.media:description:
Four Iranian men accused of plotting to kidnap a New York-based activist, have been charged in the US. Iranian-American Masih Alinejad is a prominent critic of the government in Tehran. She says she has received death threats for years. The FBI issued photos of the suspected mastermind of the plot, Alireza Farahani, an Iranian intelligence official. Farahani and three other intelligence operatives were charged in federal court in Manhattan, although they remain at large in Iran.
Al Jazeera’s Gabriel Elizondo reports from New York, US.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
